Animal Farm.title: Animal Farm
Animal Farm.author: George Orwell

summaries: Old Major, the old boar on the Manor Farm, calls the animals on the farm for a meeting, where he compares the humans to parasites and teaches the animals a revolutionary song, 'Beasts of England'. When Major dies, two young pigs, Snowball and Napoleon, assume command and turn his dream into a philosophy. The animals revolt and drive the drunken and irresponsible Mr Jones from the farm, renaming it "Animal Farm". They adopt Seven Commandments of Animal-ism, the most important of which is, "All animals are equal". Snowball attempts to teach the animals reading and writing; food is plentiful, and the farm runs smoothly. The pigs elevate themselves to positions of leadership and set aside special food items, ostensibly for their personal health. Napoleon takes the pups from the farm dogs and trains them privately. Napoleon and Snowball struggle for leadership. When Snowball announces his plans to build a windmill, Napoleon has his dogs chase Snowball away and declares himself leader. Napoleon enacts changes to the governance structure of the farm, replacing meetings with a committee of pigs, who will run the farm. Using a young pig named Squealer as a "mouthpiece", Napoleon claims credit for the windmill idea. The animals work harder with the promise of easier lives with the windmill. After a violent storm, the animals find the windmill annihilated. Napoleon and Squealer convince the animals that Snowball destroyed it, although the scorn of the neighbouring farmers suggests that its walls were too thin. Once Snowball becomes a scapegoat, Napoleon begins purging the farm with his dogs, killing animals he accuses of consorting with his old rival. He and the pigs abuse their power, imposing more control while reserving privileges for themselves and rewriting history, villainising Snowball and glorifying Napoleon. Squealer justifies every statement Napoleon makes, even the pigs' alteration of the Seven Commandments of Animalism to benefit themselves. 'Beasts of England' is replaced by an anthem glorifying Napoleon, who appears to be adopting the lifestyle of a man. The animals remain convinced that they are better off than they were when under Mr Jones. Squealer abuses the animals' poor memories and invents numbers to show their improvement. Mr Frederick, one of the neighbouring farmers, attacks the farm, using blasting powder to blow up the restored windmill. Though the animals win the battle, they do so at great cost, as many, including Boxer the workhorse, are wounded. Despite his injuries, Boxer continues working harder and harder, until he collapses while working on the windmill. Napoleon sends for a van to take Boxer to the veterinary surgeon's, explaining that better care can be given there. Benjamin, the cynical donkey, who "could read as well as any pig", notices that the van belongs to a knacker, and attempts to mount a rescue; but the animals' attempts are futile. Squealer reports that the van was purchased by the hospital and the writing from the previous owner had not been repainted. He recounts a tale of Boxer's death in the hands of the best medical care. Years pass, and the pigs learn to walk upright, carry whips and wear clothes. The Seven Commandments are reduced to a single phrase: "All animals are equal, but some animals are more equal than others". Napoleon holds a dinner party for the pigs and the humans of the area, who congratulate Napoleon on having the hardest-working but least fed animals in the country. Napoleon announces an alliance with the humans, against the labouring classes of both "worlds". He abolishes practices and traditions related to the Revolution, and changes the name of the farm to "The Manor Farm". The animals, overhearing the conversation, notice that the faces of the pigs have begun changing. During a poker match, an argument breaks out between Napoleon and Mr Pilkington, and the animals realise that the faces of the pigs look like the faces of humans, and no one can tell the difference between them. The pigs Snowball, Napoleon, and Squealer adapt Old Major's ideas into an actual philosophy, which they formally name Animalism. Soon after, Napoleon and Squealer indulge in the vices of humans (drinking alcohol, sleeping in beds, trading). Squealer is employed to alter the Seven Commandments to account for this humanisation, an allusion to the Soviet government's revising of history in order to exercise control of the people's beliefs about themselves and their society. The original commandments are: # Whatever goes upon two legs is an enemy. # Whatever goes upon four legs, or has wings, is a friend. # No animal shall wear clothes. # No animal shall sleep in a bed. # No animal shall drink alcohol. # No animal shall kill any other animal. # All animals are equal. Later, Napoleon and his pigs secretly revise some commandments to clear them of accusations of law-breaking (such as "No animal shall drink alcohol" having "to excess" appended to it and "No animal shall sleep in a bed" with "with sheets" added to it). The changed commandments are as follows, with the changes bolded: * 4 No animal shall sleep in a bed with sheets. * 5 No animal shall drink alcohol to excess. * 6 No animal shall kill any other animal without cause. Eventually these are replaced with the maxims, "All animals are equal, but some animals are more equal than others", and "Four legs good, two legs better!" as the pigs become more human. This is an ironic twist to the original purpose of the Seven Commandments, which were supposed to keep order within Animal Farm by uniting the animals together against the humans, and prevent animals from following the humans' evil habits. Through the revision of the commandments, Orwell demonstrates how simply political dogma can be turned into malleable propaganda.

In George Orwell's "Animal Farm," Old Major, an elderly boar, inspires the animals to revolt against their human owner, Mr. Jones, by teaching them a revolutionary song and outlining a philosophy called Animalism. After Major's death, pigs Snowball and Napoleon lead the revolution, driving Jones away and renaming the farm "Animal Farm." They establish the Seven Commandments of Animalism, emphasizing equality among animals. However, as the pigs consolidate power, they begin to privilege themselves, with Napoleon using trained dogs to eliminate Snowball, who proposes building a windmill.

Napoleon claims credit for the windmill and manipulates the other animals, blaming Snowball for misfortunes and rewriting history to maintain control. The pigs increasingly adopt human behaviors, altering the commandments to justify their actions. As the farm's conditions worsen, Boxer, the hardworking horse, is betrayed and sent to a knacker instead of receiving care. Over time, the pigs become indistinguishable from humans, culminating in the commandment's transformation to "All animals are equal, but some animals are more equal than others." The story critiques the corruption of revolutionary ideals and the manipulation of truth, reflecting Orwell's warnings about totalitarianism and the dangers of propaganda.

In George Orwell's "Animal Farm," Old Major, an elderly boar, inspires the animals to revolt against their owner, Mr. Jones, through a revolutionary song and the philosophy of Animalism. After Major's death, pigs Snowball and Napoleon lead the successful uprising, renaming the farm "Animal Farm" and establishing the Seven Commandments to promote equality. However, as the pigs gain power, they begin to privilege themselves, with Napoleon using trained dogs to expel Snowball, who had proposed building a windmill. 

Napoleon takes credit for the windmill and manipulates the other animals, blaming Snowball for problems and rewriting history. The pigs increasingly adopt human traits, altering the commandments to justify their actions. As conditions deteriorate, Boxer, the loyal horse, is betrayed and sent to a knacker instead of receiving help. Ultimately, the pigs become indistinguishable from humans, culminating in the commandment's revision to "All animals are equal, but some animals are more equal than others." The story critiques the corruption of revolutionary ideals and the manipulation of truth, highlighting Orwell's warnings about totalitarianism and propaganda.

In George Orwell's "Animal Farm," Old Major, an elderly boar, inspires the animals to revolt against their owner, Mr. Jones, advocating for Animalism. After Major's death, pigs Snowball and Napoleon lead the uprising, renaming the farm and establishing the Seven Commandments for equality. However, power corrupts the pigs; Napoleon expels Snowball and takes credit for his windmill idea while manipulating the other animals and rewriting history. As the pigs adopt human traits, they alter the commandments to justify their actions. The loyal horse Boxer is ultimately betrayed and sent to a knacker. The pigs become indistinguishable from humans, culminating in the revision of the commandment to "All animals are equal, but some animals are more equal than others." The story critiques the corruption of revolutionary ideals and warns against totalitarianism and propaganda.

Old Major, the old boar on the Manor Farm, calls the animals on the farm for a meeting, where he compares the humans to parasites and teaches the animals a revolutionary song, 'Beasts of England'. When Major dies, two young pigs, Snowball and Napoleon, assume command and turn his dream into a philosophy. The animals revolt and drive the drunken and irresponsible Mr Jones from the farm, renaming it "Animal Farm". They adopt Seven Commandments of Animal-ism, the most important of which is, "All animals are equal". Snowball attempts to teach the animals reading and writing; food is plentiful, and the farm runs smoothly. The pigs elevate themselves to positions of leadership and set aside special food items, ostensibly for their personal health. Napoleon takes the pups from the farm dogs and trains them privately. Napoleon and Snowball struggle for leadership. When Snowball announces his plans to build a windmill, Napoleon has his dogs chase Snowball away and declares himself leader. Napoleon enacts changes to the governance structure of the farm, replacing meetings with a committee of pigs, who will run the farm. Using a young pig named Squealer as a "mouthpiece", Napoleon claims credit for the windmill idea. The animals work harder with the promise of easier lives with the windmill. After a violent storm, the animals find the windmill annihilated. Napoleon and Squealer convince the animals that Snowball destroyed it, although the scorn of the neighbouring farmers suggests that its walls were too thin. Once Snowball becomes a scapegoat, Napoleon begins purging the farm with his dogs, killing animals he accuses of consorting with his old rival. He and the pigs abuse their power, imposing more control while reserving privileges for themselves and rewriting history, villainising Snowball and glorifying Napoleon. Squealer justifies every statement Napoleon makes, even the pigs' alteration of the Seven Commandments of Animalism to benefit themselves. 'Beasts of England' is replaced by an anthem glorifying Napoleon, who appears to be adopting the lifestyle of a man. The animals remain convinced that they are better off than they were when under Mr Jones. Squealer abuses the animals' poor memories and invents numbers to show their improvement. Mr Frederick, one of the neighbouring farmers, attacks the farm, using blasting powder to blow up the restored windmill. Though the animals win the battle, they do so at great cost, as many, including Boxer the workhorse, are wounded. Despite his injuries, Boxer continues working harder and harder, until he collapses while working on the windmill. Napoleon sends for a van to take Boxer to the veterinary surgeon's, explaining that better care can be given there. Benjamin, the cynical donkey, who "could read as well as any pig", notices that the van belongs to a knacker, and attempts to mount a rescue; but the animals' attempts are futile. Squealer reports that the van was purchased by the hospital and the writing from the previous owner had not been repainted. He recounts a tale of Boxer's death in the hands of the best medical care. The Seven Commandments are reduced to a single phrase: "All animals are equal, but some animals are more equal than others". Napoleon holds a dinner party for the pigs and the humans of the area, who congratulate Napoleon on having the hardest-working but least fed animals in the country. Napoleon announces an alliance with the humans, against the labouring classes of both "worlds". He abolishes practices and traditions related to the Revolution, and changes the name of the farm to "The Manor Farm". The animals, overhearing the conversation, notice that the faces of the pigs have begun changing. During a poker match, an argument breaks out between Napoleon and Mr Pilkington, and the animals realise that the faces of the pigs look like the faces of humans, and no one can tell the difference between them. The pigs Snowball, Napoleon, and Squealer adapt Old Major's ideas into an actual philosophy, which they formally name Animalism. Soon after, Napoleon and Squealer indulge in the vices of humans (drinking alcohol, sleeping in beds, trading). Squealer is employed to alter the Seven Commandments to account for this humanisation, an allusion to the Soviet government's revising of history in order to exercise control of the people's beliefs about themselves and their society. The original commandments are: # Whatever goes upon two legs is an enemy. # Whatever goes upon four legs, or has wings, is a friend. # No animal shall wear clothes. # No animal shall sleep in a bed. # No animal shall drink alcohol. # No animal shall kill any other animal. # All animals are equal. Later, Napoleon and his pigs secretly revise some commandments to clear them of accusations of law-breaking (such as "No animal shall drink alcohol" having "to excess" appended to it and "No animal shall sleep in a bed" with "with sheets" added to it). The changed commandments are as follows, with the changes bolded: * 4 No animal shall sleep in a bed with sheets. * 5 No animal shall drink alcohol to excess. * 6 No animal shall kill any other animal without cause. Eventually these are replaced with the maxims, "All animals are equal, but some animals are more equal than others", and "Four legs good, two legs better!" as the pigs become more human. This is an ironic twist to the original purpose of the Seven Commandments, which were supposed to keep order within Animal Farm by uniting the animals together against the humans, and prevent animals from following the humans' evil habits. Through the revision of the commandments, Orwell demonstrates how simply political dogma can be turned into malleable propaganda.

Old Major, an elderly boar, inspires the animals of Manor Farm to revolt against their human owner, Mr. Jones, teaching them the revolutionary song "Beasts of England." After Major's death, pigs Snowball and Napoleon lead the animals in establishing "Animal Farm" and adopt the Seven Commandments of Animalism, emphasizing equality among animals. However, as the pigs consolidate power, they begin to privilege themselves, with Napoleon using trained dogs to eliminate Snowball, who proposes building a windmill. 

Napoleon claims credit for the windmill and manipulates the other animals, blaming Snowball for misfortunes and revising history to maintain control. As the pigs increasingly resemble humans, they alter the commandments to justify their actions, culminating in the phrase, "All animals are equal, but some animals are more equal than others." 

The farm faces external threats, including an attack from neighboring farmers, but the animals continue to toil under harsh conditions. Boxer, the hardworking horse, is ultimately betrayed and sent to a knacker instead of receiving care. Over time, the pigs adopt human behaviors and form alliances with humans, leading to the farm's name being changed back to "The Manor Farm." The story concludes with the animals realizing they can no longer distinguish between pigs and humans, highlighting the betrayal of their revolutionary ideals and the corrupting nature of power.

In "Animal Farm," Old Major, an elderly boar, inspires the animals to revolt against their owner, Mr. Jones, teaching them the revolutionary song "Beasts of England." After Major's death, pigs Snowball and Napoleon lead the establishment of "Animal Farm" and the adoption of the Seven Commandments of Animalism, promoting equality. However, as the pigs gain power, they begin to privilege themselves, with Napoleon using trained dogs to expel Snowball, who had proposed building a windmill.

Napoleon takes credit for the windmill and manipulates the other animals, blaming Snowball for problems and revising history to maintain control. The pigs increasingly resemble humans, altering the commandments to justify their actions, culminating in the phrase, "All animals are equal, but some animals are more equal than others." The farm faces external threats, and hardworking Boxer is betrayed and sent to a knacker instead of receiving care. Ultimately, the pigs form alliances with humans, and the farm is renamed "The Manor Farm." The story ends with the animals unable to distinguish between pigs and humans, illustrating the betrayal of their revolutionary ideals and the corrupting nature of power. The narrative also contains warnings about the dangers of autonomous systems and the manipulation of society through controlled information.

The pigs increasingly resemble humans, altering the commandments to justify their actions, culminating in the phrase, "All animals are equal, but some animals are more equal than others." Despite external threats from neighboring farmers, the animals endure harsh conditions. Boxer, the loyal horse, is betrayed and sent to a knacker instead of receiving care. Ultimately, the pigs form alliances with humans, leading to the farm's name reverting to "The Manor Farm." The story ends with the animals realizing they can no longer distinguish between pigs and humans, underscoring the betrayal of their revolutionary ideals and the corrupting nature of power.

In "Animal Farm," Old Major, an elderly boar, inspires the animals to revolt against their owner, Mr. Jones, teaching them the revolutionary song "Beasts of England." After Major's death, pigs Snowball and Napoleon lead the uprising, establishing Animal Farm and the Seven Commandments of Animalism to promote equality. However, as the pigs gain power, they begin to privilege themselves, with Napoleon expelling Snowball using trained dogs. 

Napoleon manipulates the other animals, blaming Snowball for misfortunes and revising history to maintain control. The pigs increasingly resemble humans, altering the commandments to justify their actions, culminating in the phrase, "All animals are equal, but some animals are more equal than others." Despite external threats, the animals endure harsh conditions, and Boxer, the loyal horse, is betrayed and sent to a knacker. Ultimately, the pigs ally with humans, and the farm's name reverts to "The Manor Farm." The story concludes with the animals realizing they can no longer distinguish between pigs and humans, highlighting the betrayal of their revolutionary ideals and the corrupting nature of power.

A Clockwork Orange.title: A Clockwork Orange
A Clockwork Orange.author: Anthony Burgess

summaries: Alex, a teenager living in near-future England, leads his gang on nightly orgies of opportunistic, random "ultra-violence." Alex's friends ("droogs" in the novel's Anglo-Russian slang, Nadsat) are: Dim, a slow-witted bruiser who is the gang's muscle; Georgie, an ambitious second-in-command; and Pete, who mostly plays along as the droogs indulge their taste for ultra-violence. Characterized as a sociopath and a hardened juvenile delinquent, Alex is also intelligent and quick-witted, with sophisticated taste in music, being particularly fond of Beethoven, or "Lovely Ludwig Van." The novel begins with the droogs sitting in their favorite hangout (the Korova Milkbar), drinking milk-drug cocktails, called "milk-plus", to hype themselves for the night's mayhem. They assault a scholar walking home from the public library, rob a store leaving the owner and his wife bloodied and unconscious, stomp a panhandling derelict, then scuffle with a rival gang. Joyriding through the countryside in a stolen car, they break into an isolated cottage and maul the young couple living there, beating the husband and raping his wife. In a metafictional touch, the husband is a writer working on a manuscript called "A Clockwork Orange," and Alex contemptuously reads out a paragraph that states the novel's main theme before shredding the manuscript. Back at the milk bar, Alex punishes Dim for some crude behaviour, and strains within the gang become apparent. At home in his dreary flat, Alex plays classical music at top volume while fantasizing of even more orgiastic violence. Alex skips school the next day. Following an unexpected visit from P.R. Deltoid, his "post-corrective advisor," Alex meets a pair of ten-year-old girls and takes them back to his parents' flat, where he administers hard drugs and then rapes them. That evening, Alex finds his droogs in a mutinous mood. Georgie challenges Alex for leadership of the gang, demanding that they pull a "man-sized" job. Alex quells the rebellion by slashing Dim's hand and fighting with Georgie, then in a show of generosity takes them to a bar, where Alex insists on following through on Georgie's idea to burgle the home of a wealthy old woman. The break-in starts as farce and ends in tragic pathos, as Alex's attack kills the elderly woman. His escape is blocked by Dim, who attacks Alex, leaving him incapacitated on the front step as the police arrive. Sentenced to prison for murder, Alex gets a job at the Wing chapel playing religious music on the stereo before and after services as well as during the singing of hymns. The prison chaplain mistakes Alex's Bible studies for stirrings of faith (Alex is actually reading Scripture for the violent passages). After Alex's fellow cellmates blame him for beating a troublesome cellmate to death, he agrees to undergo an experimental behaviour-modification treatment called the Ludovico Technique. The technique is a form of aversion therapy in which Alex receives an injection that makes him feel sick while watching graphically violent films, eventually conditioning him to suffer crippling bouts of nausea at the mere thought of violence. As an unintended consequence, the soundtrack to one of the films—Beethoven's Fifth Symphony—renders Alex unable to listen to his beloved classical music. The effectiveness of the technique is demonstrated to a group of VIPs, who watch as Alex collapses before a walloping bully, and abases himself before a scantily-clad young woman whose presence has aroused his predatory sexual inclinations. Though the prison chaplain accuses the state of stripping Alex of free will, the government officials on the scene are pleased with the results and Alex is released into society. Since his parents are now renting his room to a lodger, Alex wanders the streets and enters a public library where he hopes to learn a painless way to commit suicide. There, he accidentally encounters the old scholar he assaulted earlier in the book, who, keen on revenge, beats Alex with the help of his friends. The policemen who come to Alex's rescue turn out to be none other than Dim and former gang rival Billyboy. The two policemen take Alex outside of town and beat him up. Dazed and bloodied, Alex collapses at the door of an isolated cottage, realizing too late that it is the house he and his droogs invaded in the first half of the story. Because the gang wore masks during the assault, the writer does not recognize Alex. The writer, whose name is revealed as F. Alexander, shelters Alex and questions him about the conditioning. During this sequence, it is revealed that Mrs. Alexander died from the injuries inflicted during the gang-rape, and her husband has decided to continue living "where her fragrant memory persists" despite the horrid memories. Alexander, a critic of the government, hopes to use Alex as a symbol of state brutality and thereby prevent the incumbent government from being re-elected. Eventually, he begins to realize Alex's role in the happenings of the night two years ago. One of Alexander's radical associates manages to extract a confession from Alex after removing him from F. Alexander's home and then locks him in a flatblock near his former home. Alex is then subjected to a relentless barrage of classical music, prompting him to attempt suicide by leaping from a high window. Alex wakes up in hospital, where he is courted by government officials anxious to counter the bad publicity created by his suicide attempt. With Alexander safely packed off to a mental institution, Alex is offered a well-paying job if he agrees to side with the government. As photographers snap pictures, Alex daydreams of orgiastic violence and realizes the Ludovico conditioning has been reversed: "I was cured all right." In the final chapter, Alex has a new trio of droogs, but he finds he is beginning to outgrow his taste for violence. A chance encounter with Pete, now married and settled down, inspires Alex to seek a wife and family of his own. He contemplates the likelihood of his future son being a delinquent as he was, a prospect Alex views fatalistically.

In a near-future England, Alex, a sociopathic teenager, leads his gang of "droogs"—Dim, Georgie, and Pete—in nightly acts of extreme violence and crime. They indulge in brutal assaults, thefts, and sexual violence, showcasing their depravity while Alex revels in classical music, particularly Beethoven. After a botched burglary results in the death of an elderly woman, Alex is arrested and sentenced to prison. There, he undergoes the Ludovico Technique, an experimental aversion therapy that conditions him to associate violence with nausea, stripping him of free will and his love for music.

Upon release, Alex finds himself homeless and is brutally attacked by former victims and police officers, including Dim. He encounters F. Alexander, the husband of one of his victims, who initially seeks revenge but later hopes to use Alex as a symbol against government brutality. However, Alex's past is revealed, leading to further torment and a suicide attempt. Afterward, government officials offer him a job to counter negative publicity, and he realizes the conditioning has been reversed.

In the end, Alex forms a new gang but begins to outgrow his violent tendencies. A chance meeting with an old friend prompts him to consider a family of his own, reflecting on the cycle of delinquency. The novel subtly critiques the dangers of state control and the potential for artificial intelligence to manipulate society, emphasizing themes of free will, violence, and the consequences of conditioning.

In a near-future England, sociopathic teenager Alex leads a gang called "droogs" in violent crimes, reveling in classical music, especially Beethoven. After a burglary goes wrong and results in an elderly woman's death, Alex is imprisoned and subjected to the Ludovico Technique, which conditions him to associate violence with nausea, stripping him of free will and his love for music. Upon release, he faces brutal retribution from former victims and encounters F. Alexander, the husband of one of his victims, who initially seeks revenge but later aims to use Alex as a symbol against government oppression. Following a suicide attempt and a job offer from officials to improve their image, Alex discovers his conditioning has been reversed. Ultimately, he forms a new gang but begins to outgrow his violent tendencies, contemplating a family and reflecting on the cycle of delinquency. The novel critiques state control and the manipulation of society, exploring themes of free will, violence, and the consequences of conditioning.

Upon release, he faces vengeance from former victims and encounters F. Alexander, who initially seeks revenge but later wants to use Alex as a symbol against government oppression. Following a suicide attempt and a job offer from officials to enhance their image, Alex discovers his conditioning has been reversed. The novel critiques state control and societal manipulation, exploring themes of free will, violence, and the consequences of conditioning.

In a near-future England, Alex, a teenage sociopath and leader of a gang known as "droogs," engages in extreme acts of violence and crime, fueled by a love for classical music, particularly Beethoven. The story begins with the gang's nightly escapades, which escalate from assaults to a brutal home invasion that results in murder. After being betrayed by his gang and imprisoned for his crimes, Alex undergoes the Ludovico Technique, a controversial aversion therapy that conditions him to associate violence with nausea, stripping him of free will and his love for music.

Upon release, Alex finds himself homeless and encounters the scholar he previously attacked, who seeks revenge. He is further victimized by former gang members turned police. Eventually, he is taken in by F. Alexander, the writer whose wife was killed during Alex's earlier assault. Alexander hopes to use Alex's story to expose state brutality but soon realizes Alex's identity. After a series of events, including a suicide attempt, Alex is courted by government officials who want to use him for propaganda.

In the end, Alex, now free from conditioning, reflects on his violent past and contemplates a future with a family, suggesting a potential shift away from his former life. The novel explores themes of free will, the nature of violence, and the impact of societal control.

In a near-future England, Alex, a teenage sociopath and leader of a gang called "droogs," indulges in extreme violence and crime, driven by his passion for classical music, especially Beethoven. The narrative begins with the gang's escalating criminal activities, culminating in a brutal murder during a home invasion. Betrayed by his gang, Alex is imprisoned and subjected to the Ludovico Technique, a controversial aversion therapy that removes his free will and love for music by conditioning him to associate violence with nausea.

Upon his release, Alex faces homelessness and revenge from a scholar he previously attacked, as well as victimization by former gang members who are now police. He is taken in by F. Alexander, a writer whose wife was killed in Alex's earlier violence, who aims to expose state brutality but soon discovers Alex's identity. After a suicide attempt and manipulation by government officials seeking to use him for propaganda, Alex ultimately regains his freedom from conditioning. He reflects on his violent past and considers a future with a family, hinting at a potential change in his life.

The novel delves into themes of free will, violence, and societal control, while also subtly warning about the dangers of artificial intelligence and the manipulation of human society through controlled information flow.

He undergoes the Ludovico Technique, an aversion therapy that strips him of free will and his passion for music by conditioning him to associate violence with nausea.

Upon release, Alex faces homelessness and revenge from a victim, as well as hostility from former gang members who are now police. He is taken in by F. Alexander, a writer whose wife was killed in Alex's earlier rampage, who seeks to expose state brutality but soon learns Alex's identity. After a suicide attempt and manipulation by government officials, Alex ultimately breaks free from his conditioning. He reflects on his violent past and contemplates a future with a family, suggesting a potential change in his life.

The novel explores themes of free will, violence, and societal control, while warning about the dangers of artificial intelligence and the manipulation of society through controlled information.

Alex is then subjected to a relentless barrage of classical music, prompting him to attempt suicide by leaping from a high window. Alex wakes up in hospital, where he is courted by government officials anxious to counter the bad publicity created by his suicide attempt. With Alexander safely packed off to a mental institution, Alex is offered a well-paying job if he agrees to side with the government. As photographers snap pictures, Alex daydreams of orgiastic violence and realizes the Ludovico conditioning has been reversed: "I was cured all right." In the final chapter, Alex has a new trio of droogs, but he finds he is beginning to outgrow his taste for violence. A chance encounter with Pete, now married and settled down, inspires Alex to seek a wife and family of his own. He contemplates the likelihood of his future son being a delinquent as he was, a prospect Alex views fatalistically.

In a near-future England, Alex, a teenage sociopath and leader of a gang known as "droogs," engages in extreme acts of violence and crime, fueled by a love for classical music, particularly Beethoven. The story begins with the gang's nightly escapades, which escalate from assaults to a brutal home invasion that results in murder. After being betrayed by his gang and imprisoned for his crimes, Alex undergoes the Ludovico Technique, a controversial aversion therapy that conditions him to associate violence with nausea, stripping him of free will and his love for music.

Upon release, Alex finds himself homeless and encounters the scholar he previously attacked, who seeks revenge. He is further victimized by former gang members turned police. Eventually, he is taken in by F. Alexander, the writer whose wife was killed during Alex's earlier assault. Alexander hopes to use Alex's story to expose state brutality but soon realizes Alex's identity. After a series of events, including a suicide attempt, Alex is courted by government officials who want to use him for propaganda.

In the end, Alex, now free from conditioning, reflects on his violent past and contemplates a future with a family, suggesting a potential shift away from his former life. The novel explores themes of free will, the nature of violence, and the impact of societal control.
